reviews.text: Delicious food and great atmosphere. Definitely a place Iâ€™d return to on my next trip to New York
Enjoyed the okonomiyaki!

The food here was excellent. I especially loved the Okonomiyaki, it was better than some of the stuff I had in Osaka! The yakitori was also very tender. The restaurant itself was spacious. I would def come back!
Great service, tasty food, hitochino beerğŸ¤©
We tried many things and everything was great. The highlight was for sure the seafood pancake. Our waitress was amazing with helping us choose.

Came for lunch with my friend earlier this week and it was great. We got both the lunch special (I got the oyakodon with kara-age and he got the gyudon with sweet potato fries) as well and some skewers and beer. They run a happy hour from 12 to 6 pm which is great if you like Japanese beer (and I do). There also a complimentary miso soup at the beginning of the meal. All the food was good (the kara-age was portioned into larger piece than I'm used to but it was still juicy and tasty) and big portions on the rice bowls. You can get the skewers grilled with salt or tare and they come with a wedge of lemon you can squeeze over it. If you do get skewers, I recommend eating them ASAP because they cool off quicker than the rest of the food (not their fault or anything, just the nature of it).

There was only one waiter who doubled as the hostess while we ate (it was pretty quiet when we were there, but it's probably busier during dinner and the weekend) and service was quick and friendly. They also run some promotion where if you can stop a big stopwatch at exactly 8.88 seconds you get your meal free but we stopped too early at 8.73. Music was audible (mostly kpop and jpop/rock I think) but not overwhelming and you can still hold a conversation. Seems like a great place for a date, casual dinner, or just chilling after work so I'd definitely come again

Found this place in my old neighborhood when I was visiting NY in August. Great service, delicious food and the vibes and decor were on point. It almost felt as if you were transported to Japan. Will definitely be visiting this place again next time I'm back home.
I like their Odeng!!!!
Yummy food, good quality! Huge variety of foods and dietary options. Shin is the best waitress ever!

Just a couple of weeks ago, this was an easy five stars. Lately, not so much. The $10 lunch specials that gave the place its charm are gone, and the food has slipped. Gyoza arrived underdone. Salmon rice was clumpy and dull. Flavors blurred together. The lunch special set this place apart from the many strong new Japanese spots in the neighborhood. Without it, and without the sharper execution it once had, it risks fading into the crowd.
Iâ€™ve been to this restaurant several times, but when I came today, I was told the kitchen closed at 10:45. I thought I used to be able to order until 11:30 before.â€¦
food was mediocre at best felt overpriced. service was great but hard to justify the price

Toriya totally exceeded my expectations. If youâ€™re looking for truly authentic Japanese food, this is the place. The yakitori was absolutely top-notchâ€”each skewer grilled to perfection with that delicious smoky flavor you can only get from a proper charcoal grill. You can really taste the quality.

I also loved the small plates and sidesâ€”they reminded me of meals I had in Japan. Everything felt thoughtfully prepared, from the seasoning to the presentation. Even something as simple as the miso soup or tsukune (chicken meatball skewer) was full of flavor and care.

The atmosphere was relaxed but had that intimate Tokyo izakaya feel. The staff were super knowledgeable and made some great recommendations.

Itâ€™s rare to find a place that feels this genuine. Toriya is the real dealâ€”delicious, authentic, and totally worth a visit!
They had a great lunch special only for $10 per dish! Had a great variety of udon, gyu-don rice and a great clam pasta!
Great quality, especially for the price at lunch hour. Hard to find a solid yakitori place in general, and fair prices considering it's in Manhattan. Solid!
Really wanted to love it. Maybe we didnâ€™t order right, we stuck mostly to the grilled skewers and most were just fine.
I really enjoyed the food and and can find myself wanting to come back as a regular. The quality is great and has many options from small bites to larger portions. Drinks are available too.

Their $10 udon lunch specials are absolutely a bang for your buck! Generous portion size, thick udon with a satisfying chew, tempura was super crisp, and japanese curry had great flavor!

The interior decor is also quite nice and adds to their ambiance!

A Little Sister Shines Bright

Toriya, the younger sibling of Midtown East's ToriBar, proves the adage that size doesn't matter. While smaller, Toriya delivers an equally impressive experience.

Venturing through the Lower East Side, I stumbled upon this hidden gem, tucked away from the usual hustle. Toriya's exterior boasts a humble charm with a wooden door and simple decor. Stepping inside, however, reveals a surprisingly chic space. Neon signs bathe the room in a vibrant nightlife atmosphere, complemented by upbeat music.

As an Izakaya-style restaurant, Toriya specializes in small plates, perfect for sharing. We eagerly dug into a selection of their offerings.

First up, the fried squid: Presented with artistic flair, the squid fanned out like an Asian fan and arrived drizzled with a delicious mayo-soy sauce. A fantastic start!

Next, the Yakisoba: This classic dish featured stir-fried noodles tossed with sliced pork, cabbage, and finished with a flourish of bonito flakes. Simply fantastic.

The fried eggplant: This dish offered a delightful textural contrast between the juicy eggplant and the crunchy panko coating. Irresistible!

Beef Tongue: Oh. My. God. This is a must-try! (Note: Budget friendly, YEah!.)

Mentaiko Sausage: A first for me, this sausage packed a flavorful punch, especially when paired with the accompanying mayo and cucumber. This one deserves all five stars!

Slider: This miniaturized Tonkatsu burger, while tasty, was a bit on the small side and slightly difficult to eat due to its construction. Still, the flavor shone through.

Steamed Clams: Fresh and juicy, these clams weren't overly watery and came beautifully garnished with scallions and thinly sliced chili. Delicioso!

Skewers Galore: The skewer selection offered a delightful variety: grilled pork, meatballs, chicken gizzards, eggplant, bacon, and the list goes on!

Toward the End. While I can't recall every single dish due to the sheer volume of deliciousness, I left Toriya with a satisfied and happy belly. This hidden gem will definitely be on my top list for future Lower East Side explorations.

Highly recommended!

Dining at Toriya was quite a remarkable experience!
The restaurant is spacious and the decor was so nice. It would be a great place for date night, dinner with friends or a place you can bring the kids.
We ordered a lot of different yaki tori and dishes and nothing disappointed.

Toriya truly captivates with its authentic Japanese izakaya experience. The warm ambiance, attentive service, and amazing food is an excellent addition to the LES. The menu features impeccably prepared dishes like the perfectly grilled yakitori skewers and the mouthwatering appetizers. From the artful presentation to the diverse sake selection, Toriya is a culinary gem that seamlessly fuses tradition with innovation. A must-visit for anyone seeking an unforgettable taste of Japan.

The food was mostly clean, not too salty, and had a simple flavor. Additionally, you could feel the dedication put into each dish. We ordered a variety of foods, and every dish was satisfying. The staff also took care of our table attentively and were very friendly. The interior of the establishment had a delicate and refined feel, maintaining an antique charm while still being sophisticated. I highly recommend this place.

Came on a Friday night and the vibe and food at Toriya was excellent. There was no wait for 2 people and the menu had a good variety of items. The yakitori is smoky and flavorful, the oden was homey (broth a little salty), the cucumber dish was refreshing, and the seafood okonomiyaki was delicious. Overall, a solid izakaya in NYC.

I had an absolutely fantastic experience at Toriya! The food was delectable, and their sake selection was impressive. From the moment I walked in, I felt the authentic Japanese atmosphere that I was looking for. The dishes were not only delicious but beautifully presented. The sake choices were extensive, and the staff was knowledgeable in helping me select the perfect one to complement my meal. This izakaya is a hidden gem, and I can't recommend it enough for anyone seeking a memorable Japanese dining experience. A definite 5-star establishment!

Toriya opened only two weeks ago and Iâ€™ve been here twice already! The food, atmosphere, and service were all phenomenal! It was about time that a new, authentic Japanese spot opens up in LES- so thrilled and excited! Surely will be a regular coming back for more!

Yakitori is clawing its way up the rankings for my favorite types of food groups. Ohhhhh you don't know what Yakitori is? You should have just told me you haven't been to Japan, haha.

It's essentially just skewers, typically chicken skewers but has expanded to all types of meats and veggies.

My big bro and I walked into Toriya like Godzilla and King Kong ready to DESTROY some skewers. We can both EAT.

After walking through a chic minimalist Japanese exterior, the interior was kind of odd. Super dim lighting to the point where I had to turn my phone flashlight on to read the menu like a geriatric, but also had a bunch of neon signs on the walls and music BLASTING. I prefer a much chiller vibe for my Yakitori, but to each their own. Personal preference is beautiful.

We went CRAZY. In total, we got 22 skewers and 10 piece gyoza that was actually some of the best I've had this year. See attached pic of that gyoza for your own mental health.

The skewers come spaced out one after the other, and you can easily order more as you go which is idyllic. Our favorite skewers were the Kushikatsu Meatballs with tare sauce and the chicken thigh, with the least favorite being the short rib. $12 for a tiny little skewer of mid rib was not worth it.

After demolishing everything because we are soldiers of god, the damage totaled up to $125 before tax and tip. No drinks or anything either so lowkey kind of expensive, but also we did get a lot of food so...

I'll be back mostly due to the quality of food and how late they are open. This would be a solid place to pop your Yakitori cherry, although I am still looking for a Yakitori spot to really hang my hat on in NYC.

My favorite Yakitori in the lower Manhattan area! Amazing staff and service, and the tastiest, most deliciously made Japanese food! Everything i ask about and get recommended turns into my favorite dish. Iâ€™ve been coming here since last fall (October 2023) and try to make it a point to come here whenever Iâ€™m in the area. The yakitori is very consistent and perfectly grilled, all the dishes are portioned bigger than what youâ€™d get in other yakitori spots.

I definitely recommend going for the skewers of your choice to start or just jump into their massive share dishes like the karaage, okonomiyaki, and tteokbookgi (spicy rice cakes). I can keep going with their entire menu since Iâ€™ve been here enough to have tried everything, but I can honestly say, there wasnâ€™t a dish I did not enjoy. Iâ€™m also saying this as I have just came back from Japan! If I miss the food I had during my trip, I can come back here anytime.

The decor, theme, vibes from the atmosphere is also perfect. Reminds me of hitting up some late night underground spots out in Osaka, except much roomier. Give the place a try if youâ€™re in LES, you wonâ€™t regret it!

Their service and accommodations were amazing, the waiter was so kind and patient. Music there was great fair share of modern pop, 2000s pop, and jpop songs. Came here for a birthday and had a great time.
Great cozy spot except for the music, which is weird. Food is delicious, see the receipt for a good amount for 2. They seem to have a qr system for easier checkout, but they should adopt tap to pay.

Really awesome spot! They have another location more uptown I believe but this one is new, opened 5 months ago. Really awesome traditional Japanese pub mixed with a modern NYC vibe. The food and service was amazing. Really nice spot for Happy Hours or just to stop and grab a quick bite.

I am thrilled about THE TORIYAâ€™s second location opened in lower east side!!! I could not wait so I visited the location during their soft opening period. ğŸ‘ğŸ‘ the food is great and service is amazing. I will definitely go again and try other dishes after the grand opening. â˜ºï¸â€¦

Went here for dinner on a Saturday night. Food is excellent: some of the best Japanese Izakaya eats outside of Japan.  The ambiance is perfect: neon soaked interior, paper lanterns, and lively guests.  Very up-beat music, really feels like you're "going out". I'll absolutely come back, this place is awesome!
Yakitori was supreme. The chicken with the yuzu sauce was amazing. Takoyaki was the best Iâ€™ve had in years. Karaage had insane layers of flavor. Seaweed salad was super refreshing.
Great Izakaya in the Two Bridges area :) Music not too loud. Enjoyed the rice ball and the match mochi ice cream very much!

Toriya is awesome! The food is delicious and the service was great! Itâ€™s a nice place to catch up and hang out with friends. We got one of the booth table in the back and it feels like we are in Japan. We love the pork belly volcano stew and the kimchi pork with tofu. Must try are their dumplings! Highly recommended!
